#### French-speaking constituencies

The 2024 Belgian federal elections, held on June 9, were marked by significant political shifts within the French-speaking constituencies, specifically in Wallonia and Brussels. In these regions, the main political players include the Mouvement Réformateur (MR), the Socialist Party (PS), and Écolo, alongside emerging parties such as the Belgian Workers' Party (PTB).

In Wallonia, the MR experienced a notable surge in support, becoming the largest French-speaking party for the first time in many years, capturing approximately 26% of the vote. This was a substantial increase from their 2019 performance, which only garnered around 16.9% of the votes. The PS, historically a dominant force in French-speaking politics, suffered a decline, securing only about 8.05% of votes and losing several seats, which underscored a shift in the political landscape toward more liberal governance within the French-speaking community <citation>https://www.brusselstimes.com/1085399/the-belgian-elections-biggest-winners-and-losers</citation>.

In Brussels, the voting dynamics reflected a similar pattern with MR leading the French-speaking candidates, followed closely by the PTB and the PS. The latter faced setbacks, indicating a change in voter preferences and priorities that were heavily influenced by issues such as migration and civil rights, which have gained prominence in recent electoral debates <citation>https://whogoverns.eu/belgiums-2024-elections-a-shift-to-the-right-though-less-extreme-than-expected</citation>.

The significant outcomes in the French-speaking constituencies pointed to an overall political realignment in Belgium, where voters showed a tendency towards more centrist and liberal parties amid a backdrop of growing right-wing sentiments throughout the country. This shift may have substantial implications for the formation of the next government, as coalition-building will be essential in navigating the divided political landscape brought forth by this election cycle <citation>https://publyon.com/belgian-elections-2024-results-and-potential-coalitions/</citation>.

As parties continue to navigate the results, it remains to be seen how these shifts will influence not just local governance but also federal coalitions and policies moving forward into the post-election period.

As the 2024 Belgian federal election approaches, opinion polls are becoming increasingly significant in gauging potential voting patterns and political preferences among the electorate. Various polling organizations have conducted surveys to assess the public's voting intentions, with results indicating a competitive political landscape.

According to the latest Ipsos poll conducted between November 18 and 21, 2024, the following voting intentions emerged: the liberal party Mouvement Réformateur (MR) leads with 27.4%, followed by the Socialist Party (PS) at 24.6%, the Environmentalist party Ecolo at 8.1%, and the Leftist party PVDA/PTB at 12.9% <citation>https://politpro.eu/en/belgium/polls/61534/ipsos/2024-11-21</citation>. ## Electoral System

The electoral system in Belgium is characterized by a proportional representation model, specifically using a party-list system. This system allows voters to cast their votes for political parties rather than individual candidates, which subsequently allocates seats in the Chamber of Representatives based on the percentage of votes each party receives in a given electoral district. Each district is assigned a number of seats correlating to its population size, thereby ensuring that representation reflects the demographic distribution across the country <citation>https://electiopedia.com/elections-in-belgium/</citation>.

Belgium’s system underwent significant changes after the sixth state reform in December 2011, which granted more powers to regional governments and led to a more complex electoral landscape <citation>https://www.expatica.com/be/living/gov-law-admin/belgium-government-106909/</citation>. Federal elections occur every five years, synchronizing with European and regional elections to streamline the voting process for citizens <citation>https://www.populationencyclopedia.com/belgium-elections/overview/</citation>.

One notable feature of the Belgian electoral system is the requirement for compulsory voting, which mandates that all eligible citizens aged 18 and over participate in elections, a measure that aims to enhance voter turnout <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/a-guide-to-the-elections-the-voting-process-in-belgium</citation>. In recent developments, legislation has also been introduced allowing 16- and 17-year-olds to vote in European elections, marking a progressive step in youth participation in the democratic process <citation>https://www.belganewsagency.eu/a-guide-to-the-elections-the-voting-process-in-belgium</citation>.

The ballots used in these elections include a list of candidates from the respective parties, with voters able to select candidates from their chosen parties. This system not only enhances voter choice but also reinforces party accountability as parties strive to appeal to their constituents to secure votes at the next election <citation>https://www.reuters.com/article/world/factbox-key-facts-about-belgiums-electoral-system-idUSL10246183</citation>.

In summary, the electoral system of Belgium is designed to promote proportionality and voter engagement while ensuring that various socio-political voices are represented in the federal government. The combination of a party-list system, compulsory voting, and recent reforms targeting youth voters signifies Belgium's commitment to a robust democratic process <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BE/BE-LC01/elections/electoral-system</citation>.
